snippet.textDisplay: I think a huge issue with getting the diagnosis, in terms of being taken seriously at the start, is that the common knowledge is periods can be painful. We all know about cramps and other uncomfortable aspects coming with it. However, if your periods become too severe to the point in which you, for example, have a hard time even walking - that's not normal. And I really hope our society can stop dismissing these cases as "normal period cramps". Thank you for making this video, Tati. xx
snippet.textOriginal: I think a huge issue with getting the diagnosis, in terms of being taken seriously at the start, is that the common knowledge is periods can be painful. We all know about cramps and other uncomfortable aspects coming with it. However, if your periods become too severe to the point in which you, for example, have a hard time even walking - that's _not_ normal. And I really hope our society can stop dismissing these cases as "normal period cramps". Thank you for making this video, Tati. xx

snippet.textDisplay: I am an American currently living in the UK. Although the NHS has its flaws, it is unbelievable how much better it is than the American health care system. I sliced off the tip of my finger, went to the ER, was seen within the hour, and walked out without any bills to pay. I as well get a half year's supply of contraceptives absolutely free, provided without questions or a doctors appointment. I am terrified to move back to the USA because I won't be able to afford health insurance. It amazes me every time I talk to someone over here who is complaining about paying such a little amount for something that would bankrupt people in the states. America needs to figure it out, because this is not the way to live.

snippet.textDisplay: I had severe endometriosis for years. You need to get surgery to remove it. It can give you cancer. It will relieve pain ease heavy flows. Mine wrapped around my colon. snippet.textDisplay: I'm currently laying in bed from my second laproscopy surgery. I was so lucky to find a second Dr who really knew what he was doing. My first surgery was in Aug of 17. I still continued to have pain and I knew the surgeries were just a bandaid so when the pain became more and more frequent I knew I needed another surgery. By this time I had been referred to another Dr from someone who majorly suffers also. Boy was I glad I did. My doctor affectionately called me 'messed up'. Most of my severe pain was from what was left behind from my first surgery that the doctor was not skilled enough to remove. The recovery has been way harder than my previous surgery and I am once again thankful that my current doctor understands that and will not accept me being in severe pain.

Im glad u did too 😘😘

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you so much for this video. I just want to rant a bit😭 when I was younger I would get so sick while getting my period, I would get such bad cramps that I couldn’t do anything but lay in bad, I would feel faint and become very pale, I would dry heave and throw up nothing but liquid. It was absolutely terrible and my mom would not take me to the OBGYN until she witnessed me dry heave out of her car door because it’s that “invisible pain” and she didn’t believe me. I finally was put onto the pill and have been on it for over two years. Recently I’ve been feeling dull and sharp pains in my ovaries, experience bloating and break tenderness, and my lower back down to my legs sometimes hurt. I think it could be endo flaring up but I’m absolutely terrified. I’m getting a pelvic exam and ultrasound done this weekend and I’m so so scared they’re going to tell me I have ovarian cysts or follicles or that I’m pregnant (which wouldn’t make sense because I take the pill correctly every day and we also use condoms) but I’m still so scared for any news😓😓

snippet.textDisplay: I got so emotional with Tati about not having insurance. First year in college away from home I was trying to figure everything out & I had an ovarian cyst that caused me to lose so much weight. I didn’t find out what I had until suffering with it for 5 months. 3 male doctors later finally my 4th doctor (female) suggested a cyst. Not a pulled muscle like the rest. Almost a thousand dollars later & then another 500 after confirming it was indeed a cyst that was causing me so much pain. So many times I went with cents to my name during that time. 2 years later & I still suffer with this cyst. Getting ultrasounds to see if anything has changed is too expensive so I have yet to know if it’s gotten bigger or not.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't have endo, but I am a Nurse Practitioner/RN, and I find women's health so fascinating--probably because I'm a woman and our bodies are so fascinating!!  :-). People also don't relaize that not only is it an inflammatory process, but when your pituitary gland is sending those hormonal pulses to your endometrium, the other scattered endometrial pieces throughout the abdomen (or wherever else they're located) receive those signals, thus increasing inflammation and pain. It's basically like all those areas are menstruating as well along with your uterus.  Every area of those endometium are sending pain signals back to the brain.    So, so painful to have and I'm so sorry you both have to go through it! SO glad you are shedding light on the subject to other women who may be going through the same issue!!

snippet.textDisplay: I‘m so glad women are starting to speak up on this. 💕I don’t have endo, but I do get all the nasty symptoms they talk about. I‘m super exhausted for at least 3 days and my last obgyn just told me: „well every woman is different an so is the pain. It’s normal.“ every time I would go there because of everything. snippet.textDisplay: I knew something was wrong, after several doctors I finally found one who sent me to a psychiatrist who actually wrote me a prescription for hysterectomy and according to my doctor, she called him and gave him a piece of her mind. Two days after my surgery the doctor told me he found out what my issue was...I had andrometrios...I had never heard that word...he told me I was bleeding into my muscle instead of out...I asked him what are the symptoms...he said "excruciating pain"... I never wanted to punch someone as much as I did him at that moment.  I had been telling him and his colleagues that for years and years.  The hysterectomy was very hard to heal from and it took over a year but it was the best thing that ever happened for me regarding pain.  I have never met a woman who made up menstrual issues and I advocate for women to not succumb to ridiculous doctors who think they know your body better than you do.

snippet.textDisplay:
i'm going on 9-10 years of... beginning in college when i went to the ER for severe pain out of nowhere, it literally paralyzed my legs temporarily - they believe i had a massive ovarian cyst rupture that caused a lot of internal bleeding and scar tissue on my organs. i got 'diagnosed' with POTS not long after that, by my primary doctor, who sent me to a cardiologist who refused to take me seriously because i was 21, and the average age of his patients were 60. i never felt so upset about how a doctor treated me. and then... i just dealt with the insane pain all the time, shaking and crying, and all i did was take pain killers for it, which a lot of the time, didn't even work much. i didn't have health insurance at this point, so i was scared to go to the doctor, and just took pain medicine. i did end up in urgent care again once, for another rupture, and i just kept getting slapped with expensive bills i couldn't afford, so i kept avoiding dealing with it.
i eventually convinced myself to go to planned parenthood about it, i did have to pay quite a bit for it, because i was living with my boyfriend at the time and he earned a reasonable enough salary. they just gave me a birth control, which many months later, i stopped taking because i was so ill for hours every time i took it. i got married in 2018, and finally got health insurance i could afford. got a primary doctor, found she didn't help... much. gave me a different birth control, same thing ended up happening, took it for several months, but kept feeling really ill, so gave up.
it just feels like, no one cares, and health professionals don't really want to help you out, you're always a bother to them. nearing the end of 2019 i went to my doctor and told them i wanted a referral to a gyno. i went there for the first time in 2020, and i told a bunch of my symptoms to the new gyno. i feel like it's starting on the same path, i just started a new birth control a few weeks ago - but at least this doctor, i feel like she cares, and she talked about the process and plans and steps. we'll see how this works out, and then what we'd move to next if it doesn't, etc. etc. it's just kind of frustrating, because i've had so many symptoms for so many years, and i get fed a lot of bull, and then i hear all these stories from others, and it's good to feel not alone, but i feel so angry that they struggle and then i struggle. it's basically ring around the rosie with women's health issues. i technically haven't been officially diagnosed with endo, but none of my doctor's will officially diagnose me with anything, i just get 'i think it's this', so it's like i'm carrying around 5-6 prognoses at this point.

snippet.textDisplay: I really appreciated when she talked about the bleeding situation at school. My biggest problem in school was teachers not allowing my to use the restroom. They would say you have gone to the bathroom everyday in my class for a week but the truth was I went to the bathroom in every class and in between classes sometimes (risking being late) because I couldn't make it the hour class long without bleeding through my pants and all over the chair. and I had THICK, LONG pads. I had to always wear underwear, spanx then pants plus a long shirt or sweater and then left it up out of the way so when I stood up I would put it down and wear my backpack to my knees and side of the chair slowly to wipe off the blood on my seat because I bleed through EVERY SINGLE TIME.

snippet.textDisplay: Hi Tati, I loved this video! I have been watching your videos since the very beginning and they have always brought me so much happiness and helped me through some of my worst days! I struggle with a genetic consisting called Ehlers Danlos Syndrome. There are 13 different sub types, and I have the 3rd type that primarily affects my joints. It leaves me in constant pain and affects many of my other organs. I just want to say thank you for being an advocate. Like endo, EDS is extremely under diagnosed! I spent years feeling like i was crazy! Thank you for constantly being such an amazing role model!

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you, thank you for bringing awareness to this HORRIBLE illness, I was diagnosed 2 years ago and I KNEW the pain wasn't in my head, I went from: I have low pain tolerance, to it's my high blood sugar, I need to lose weight, to FINALLY having a dr listen to me after I spent a day on the floor vomiting from my period pain that month. I was diagnosed with Stage III, with the tissue connecting, my ovaries, uterus, bladder, and rectum along with 2 chocolate cysts that almost made me have to remove my left ovary. I also know the feeling with no insurance. When I first suspected something was wrong I couldn't do anything about it, because I couldn't afford the treatment I needed at the time.

snippet.textDisplay: I was told it was all in my head for two decades.  I actually had a triage nurse once tell me the pain was gas and I should go home and take Gas-x.  Two hours later I was in surgery.  It angered me that a fellow female could so easily dismiss my severe lower abdominal pain as gas, even after I told her that I know what gas feels like, and it wasn’t just gas.  Cut to many years later, and I finally found a savvy physician who LISTENED to me.  After 20 years of unnecessary suffering, I now have relief.  Of course, I still have occasional flare-ups, but those are rare.  The most devastating thing about having endo and, in my case, also PCOS, is infertility.  I love children.  I wanted babies.  I was never able to conceive.  Life’s a roller coaster.  If your doctor won’t listen, find another doctor.  If that one won’t listen, get another one.  Keep changing doctors, until you find a good one.  My doctor is in his 60s.  I pray he never retires, because good doctors are hard to find, like a needle in a haystack.  Thanks Tati and Erika for demystifying female reproductive issues.  Let’s all make a point of following suit and talking about this more often.  Wombs are not dirty.  Ovaries aren’t naughty.  Menstrual periods aren’t taboo.  Let’s all demystify our reproductive issues.

snippet.textDisplay: I love this so much. This is a struggle that tons of women are going through but it doesn’t really get talked about. My husband and I have been married for 5 years and we were struggling to get pregnant. That’s when I went to my dr and found out I have endo. So there’s this struggle of do I continue to take my birth control so I’m not in excruciating pain every month due to endo? Because I know the second I stop it to try to get pregnant it’ll just be months of torture. And how many months do you go through the torture before you give up again of trying to get pregnant and go back on birth control? It sucks.

snippet.textDisplay:
It's amazing that this was published the day of my excision surgery. I'm so happy to see you talking about this and raising awareness about endometriosis. I lived for years without a diagnosis or support systems when I was in pain. Thank you for putting this out there!

Unfortunately I have to go back and get another surgery in 3 to 9 months, but I'm already in shock that somehow recovering from being cut into is less painful than my previous flare ups.
